content.text: Complex arguments may have many propositional variables, making it hard to guess a counterexample. Systematic methods like **truth tables** or **semantic tableaux** can help.
For truth tables: list all possible truth-value combinations, evaluate premises and conclusion for each, then check if any row has true premises and false conclusion.

content.definition: An interpretation (assignment of truth values to atomic propositions) that makes all premises true and the conclusion false. Finding one proves invalidity.

content.title: Systematic Search
premises: Argument: (P → Q) → R, P → R ∴ P → Q
Goal: Find P, Q, R making premises true, conclusion false
Conclusion false: P = T, Q = F (so P → Q = F)
Check P → R: need R = T
Counterexample: P = T, Q = F, R = T
content.note: Working backwards from 'conclusion false' often simplifies the search.

content.text: Strategy: Start with the conclusion. Find assignments making it false. Then check if any of those can also make all premises true.
If no counterexample exists after exhaustive search, the argument is valid. But for complex cases, a proof is more efficient than checking all possibilities.

content.question: What is the best strategy for finding counterexamples?
options: Start by making the conclusion false
content.explanation: Start by finding truth values that make the conclusion false, then check if any of those assignments can also make all premises true. This is more efficient than random guessing.
